summary: So a pretty royal member comes to your house (Winterfell) and your family don’t like them and would even pick a fight with them...
body:
So a pretty royal member comes to your house (Winterfell) and your family don’t like them and would even pick a fight with them to protect you

I was talking about Robb and Joffrey.

Why only Sansa gets hate for it?

blog.name: aiviaisloneczko
blog.title: Welcome in Crazieland
blog.description: Mother and child in place where  weird ships happens

title: Game of thrones - alternative history
body:
I’ve just read a book about Richard the Third and apparently he wasn’t so bad like Shakespeare wrote so assumed that Game of thrones is written by victorious Starks and play a game ;)

1. Ned Stark wasn’t so noble. Yes, he was friends with king Robert but not with Lannisters and children of king, specially Joffrey, who was under Lannisters influence. Sudden king’s death has bad impact on Stark’s house so Ned claimed Robert’s children bastards and allianced with Robert’s brother - Stannis. He made an act of treason so they cut his head - that is accurate penalty for that kind of crime.

2. Sansa was as manipulative as Margaery (in the show). She was Joffrey’s fiancee and traitors daughter and there was no evidence that Joffrey was bastard. So what? Made him a monster. Even if no one belives he’s bastard, others will feel sorry for a poor girl. Joffrey cannot marry Sansa, specially when her brother was fighting against him in the same time so Sansa pick another one - Tyrion. Yes, he was an imp but also rich noble with great inheritance and king’s uncle. Not bad for daughter of traitor.

3. Robb was an idiot. He didn’t win any battle, his commanders did. Only thing he should do is marry a right girl and he failed even on that. Yeah, they sing about great love but this was a move which pissed a lot of people. Like Tywin said why is better to kill ten people at the dinner than thousand on the batterfield.

4. Tywin was genius. And everybody hates him because of that. Tyrion was jealous because he wasn’t smart like him (and btw he and Sansa actually poisoned Joffrey together) so frustrated Tyrion killed his father. We think because Tywin mistreated him but it doesn’t make sense. If Tywin was ashamed that Tyrion was imp, he could easily killed him many years before. But the first - Tywin was an enemy of Starks.

5. Poor Margaery - girl with golden heart, who was thinking about common folks (in contrary of Sansa) was viwed as manipulative and promiscuous. Well, in this story could be only one innocent virgin and it must be Sansa.

6. Arya never went to Bravos and was trained as assasin. She spend her years in Castle Black with her half brother (real half brother, all this Aegon nonsence was created later, for various reasons) and this whole thing was just an imagination of tomboy girl who stuck with all this men for years.

7. Yeah, there were really bad years for Sansa later when nothing went right. The poisoning job didn’t end up like she was planning, when they pick Margaery instead of her for the second time, her aunt died, her mother’s family wasn’t interested in war against Lannisters, her brothers were killed (for real) and her next husband was to busy defending the North from Iron Islanders to pick her cause. What is even more bad, when she supported Stannis hoping that at least him would fight against Lannisters, Ramsey defeated him too. So she run away for her last hope - her half brother Jon.

8. Jon was her father’s favourite bastard. They shared the same level of intelligence with Robb. But he was loyal and Sansa promised him that he could left the Night Watch (never a fan, he was sent there by Catelyn who was scared that Ned loved him even more than his legitimate children). So Jon went through the wall, came back with Freefolks army, killed the Watchers who disagreed with him (they never killed him - it’s just a myth) and stand against Ramsey. And he almost LOST when finally someting good happened to Sansa - her uncle Littlefinger came with another army and they defeated Ramsey so she can be a widow.

9. Well, this time Sansa was smarter - she killed her future husband before she married him. Well, Littlefinger was hoping for lucrative marriage with beautiful, young girl but he really underestimated Sansa.

10. Sansa sent Jon to Daenerys. He’s handsome womanizer so lonely Targaryen easily felt into the trap. Because the North have bigger problem - after all these years of wars people were starving and started rebellion. There is no Night King or zombie army - just a lot of desperate people who attacks castles and nobles. She needs help with that so Dany’s hiring army was ideal solution.So Jon  convince Daenerys it would be better to attack from north (specially after losing Highgarden) and before that suppress the common folks rebellion so Targaryen girl in love agreed for that.

11. I am conflicted about Cersei because I cannot unseen her as hungry power, manipulative person, just not that bad like others said.

summary: Honestly is too much to ask for a scene of Arya telling Sansa, Jon, Gendry, and the Hound (Bran probably already knows) what...
body: Honestly is too much to ask for a scene of Arya telling Sansa, Jon, Gendry, and the Hound (Bran probably already knows) what she’s been through. Just so she can talk to her loved ones about it and so they can do their best to help her heal even if they don’t understand it’s good to have someone you trust completely know what happened

reblog.comment: Honestly is too much to ask for a scene of Arya telling Sansa, Jon, Gendry, and the Hound (Bran probably already knows) what she’s been through. Just so she can talk to her loved ones about it and so they can do their best to help her heal even if they don’t understand it’s good to have someone you trust completely know what happened

summary: [[Sansan-- Clearing bodies after the battle. This is a fic I may give multiple parts too. Likes/Reblogs/Comments always...
body:
[[Sansan– Clearing bodies after the battle. This is a fic I may give multiple parts too. Likes/Reblogs/Comments always appreciated! This will be continued on AO3 (https://archiveofourown.org/works/18687181/chapters/44317873)]]

Everyone had gathered in the great room, a fire flickering in the hearth, offering a small bit of warmth and filling the space with a dull glow. Sansa watched as everyone organized themselves to the best of their abilities. She watched as Gendry spotted Arya from across the room, and ran to her, lifting her off of her feet and pulling her against his chest. Sansa watched as Daenerys walked into the room, looking stricken and defeated, and found Jon, who held her up as she sobbed. Sansa watched also as Brienne and Jaime walked into the room, a little too close for just friends.

She sighed heavily, glancing around the room. Grey Worm had found Missandei, and they were tangled in a passionate kiss. Samwell and Gilly were grinning despite the hell around them, fawning over their young child. Sansa felt the tears in her eyes, and she swallowed the lump in her throat, trying to force herself to remain composed. She wanted to feel nothing but happiness for these reunited lovers, but all she felt was envy. Envy and sorrow.

Sansa excused herself from the room, going largely unnoticed. The bodies outside needed to be cleaned-up. She could do that. She didn’t need to suppress her tears for the dead, so she let them fall as she gripped the ankles of a fallen wight, using all her strength to tug it towards the gates leading outside. “Come on,” she cried, huffing as she dragged the full weight of the thing. She glanced around. There were hundreds more. “Please,” she choked-out, giving another heave. The corpse didn’t budge, and she stared at it long and hard. She recognized it as one of her men, and sobbed again. “Move!” she shouted.

Nothing happened as she tugged, her strength waning. She closed her eyes as she made to pull the fallen soldier/wight, grunting through her tears. Shock overcame here when the body easily moved with her this time.

She opened her tear-filled eyes to see Sandor Clegane standing in front of her, easily holding the top-half of the victim and moving it with Sansa’s motions. Without words Sansa readjusted her grip, lifted the wight’s legs and moved towards the exit. Sandor silently followed.

Sansa led them out of the gate, as far as she could manage, and then gently set the bottom-half of the soldier down. She was surprised at Sandor’s gentleness as he rested the top-half of their fallen friend on the ground. 

Their eyes met and Sandor walked towards her, still saying nothing. Sansa had no words. Instead she threw herself into his chest, sobs wracking her body. She felt his strong arms wrap around her, pulling her close. 

She nuzzled deep into his broad chest. His armor had been removed, and the supple leather was warm from his body heat. The warmth was greatly welcomed. She had given her cloak to a returning fighter who had been shaking from the cold, and the air out here chilled her to the bone. “I’m cold,” she said sadly, unsure of why.

Sandor’s arms released her, and she was about to frown when she felt herself being lifted into the air. One broad arm was behind her back, the other under her knees, cradling her. She wrapped her arms around his neck, resting her head against his collarbone. Suddenly the cold melted away around her, and the utter terror in her heart and mind dulled slightly. 

Sansa lifted her head up, tentatively placing a kiss on Sandor’s scarred cheek as he walked. He stopped when she did, his brown eyes shifting down to her, his heavy brow making him look tired, and a little confused. 

She matched his gaze for a minute, before sinking back against his chest. He carried her back through the threshold of the castle, keeping her warm all the while.

Their eyes met and Sandor walked towards her, still saying nothing. Sansa had no words. Instead she threw herself into his chest, sobs wracking her body. She felt his strong arms wrap around her, pulling her close. 

She nuzzled deep into his broad chest. His armor had been removed, and the supple leather was warm from his body heat. The warmth was greatly welcomed. She had given her cloak to a returning fighter who had been shaking from the cold, and the air out here chilled her to the bone. “I’m cold,” she said sadly, unsure of why.

Sandor’s arms released her, and she was about to frown when she felt herself being lifted into the air. One broad arm was behind her back, the other under her knees, cradling her. She wrapped her arms around his neck, resting her head against his collarbone. Suddenly the cold melted away around her, and the utter terror in her heart and mind dulled slightly. 

Sansa lifted her head up, tentatively placing a kiss on Sandor’s scarred cheek as he walked. He stopped when she did, his brown eyes shifting down to her, his heavy brow making him look tired, and a little confused. 

She matched his gaze for a minute, before sinking back against his chest. He carried her back through the threshold of the castle, keeping her warm all the while.

trail.content_raw:
[[Sansan– Clearing bodies after the battle. This is a fic I may give multiple parts too. Likes/Reblogs/Comments always appreciated! This will be continued on AO3 (https://archiveofourown.org/works/18687181/chapters/44317873)]]

Everyone had gathered in the great room, a fire flickering in the hearth, offering a small bit of warmth and filling the space with a dull glow. Sansa watched as everyone organized themselves to the best of their abilities. She watched as Gendry spotted Arya from across the room, and ran to her, lifting her off of her feet and pulling her against his chest. Sansa watched as Daenerys walked into the room, looking stricken and defeated, and found Jon, who held her up as she sobbed. Sansa watched also as Brienne and Jaime walked into the room, a little too close for just friends.

She sighed heavily, glancing around the room. Grey Worm had found Missandei, and they were tangled in a passionate kiss. Samwell and Gilly were grinning despite the hell around them, fawning over their young child. Sansa felt the tears in her eyes, and she swallowed the lump in her throat, trying to force herself to remain composed. She wanted to feel nothing but happiness for these reunited lovers, but all she felt was envy. Envy and sorrow.

Sansa excused herself from the room, going largely unnoticed. The bodies outside needed to be cleaned-up. She could do that. She didn’t need to suppress her tears for the dead, so she let them fall as she gripped the ankles of a fallen wight, using all her strength to tug it towards the gates leading outside. “Come on,” she cried, huffing as she dragged the full weight of the thing. She glanced around. There were hundreds more. “Please,” she choked-out, giving another heave. The corpse didn’t budge, and she stared at it long and hard. She recognized it as one of her men, and sobbed again. “Move!” she shouted.

Nothing happened as she tugged, her strength waning. She closed her eyes as she made to pull the fallen soldier/wight, grunting through her tears. Shock overcame here when the body easily moved with her this time.

She opened her tear-filled eyes to see Sandor Clegane standing in front of her, easily holding the top-half of the victim and moving it with Sansa’s motions. Without words Sansa readjusted her grip, lifted the wight’s legs and moved towards the exit. Sandor silently followed.

Sansa led them out of the gate, as far as she could manage, and then gently set the bottom-half of the soldier down. She was surprised at Sandor’s gentleness as he rested the top-half of their fallen friend on the ground. 

Their eyes met and Sandor walked towards her, still saying nothing. Sansa had no words. Instead she threw herself into his chest, sobs wracking her body. She felt his strong arms wrap around her, pulling her close. 

She nuzzled deep into his broad chest. His armor had been removed, and the supple leather was warm from his body heat. The warmth was greatly welcomed. She had given her cloak to a returning fighter who had been shaking from the cold, and the air out here chilled her to the bone. “I’m cold,” she said sadly, unsure of why.

Sandor’s arms released her, and she was about to frown when she felt herself being lifted into the air. One broad arm was behind her back, the other under her knees, cradling her. She wrapped her arms around his neck, resting her head against his collarbone. Suddenly the cold melted away around her, and the utter terror in her heart and mind dulled slightly. 

Sansa lifted her head up, tentatively placing a kiss on Sandor’s scarred cheek as he walked. He stopped when she did, his brown eyes shifting down to her, his heavy brow making him look tired, and a little confused. 

She matched his gaze for a minute, before sinking back against his chest. He carried her back through the threshold of the castle, keeping her warm all the while.

tags: im really not this petty but im tired
summary: Typical little coward stan. Pissed when called out for nonesense, shoots back with snark and then blocks so no one can reply. 🙄...
body:
Typical little coward stan. Pissed when called out for nonesense, shoots back with snark and then blocks so no one can reply. 🙄 Your age is showing. Come back when you’ve got your big girl panties on and can actually handle a civil debate because no one was nasty, but go off I guess…

Dany did threaten Sansa. Twice in one episode. That’s canon. Period. She also didn’t “save the North” — that was a collective effort (her dragons weren’t nearly as effective as all y’all thought AND WE BEEN TELLING YOU THAT WAS GOING TO HAPPEN FOR DAMN NEAR TWO YEARS NOW). I know you’re all pissed off because we keep on getting it right and yous keep getting it wrong, but like I said.. y’all keep ignoring the signs.

Anyone who Miss Sunflowers hasn’t blocked, feel free to tag her.

blog.name: springwolvesofwinterfell
blog.title: Spring comes to Winterfell
blog.description: My personal collection of GoT/ ASoIaF

summary: Tyrion, Jorah and their true queens.  Anyone notices that Tyrion always actively seeks for Sansa’s hand or offers her his hand,...
caption:
Tyrion, Jorah and their true queens. 

Anyone notices that Tyrion always actively seeks for Sansa’s hand or offers her his hand, just like Jorah does with Dany?

Don’t forget this…

One day I pray you love someone. I pray that you love her so much. When you close your eyes, you’ll see her face, you’ll know what it feels, you’ll know what is like to love someone, to truly love someone. Before I take her from you. (Cersei to Tyrion, 2x06)

Pretty sure if Tyrion is to die in the end, the last word he would tell Sansa is: 

And now my watch has ended.

____

Gifs are not mine.

summary: Sansa survived Cersei, Littlefinger, Joffrey and Ramsay. Played a very important part in the Battle of Bastards, retaking her...
body:
Sansa survived Cersei, Littlefinger, Joffrey and Ramsay. Played a very important part in the Battle of Bastards, retaking her home along Jon. She’s responsible for Littlefinger’s and Ramsay’s deaths and watched Joffrey die. Just Cersei to go. 

Game of Thrones really has me rooting for Lady Sansa of Winterfell now. You go, queen. I bend the knee

blog.name: secretlyatargaryen
blog.title: Worms are crawling in and out of Rhaegar's ass
blog.description: Jenny. This blog consists mainly of Game of Thrones/A Song of Ice and Fire, with particular focus on Tyrion, but also among my favorites are Sansa, Cersei, Arya, and Brienne. I also occasionally post about video games or books or whatever else I find interesting.

summary: Sansa and Tyrion and The Search for the Lost Husband
title: Sansa and Tyrion and The Search for the Lost Husband
body:
It’s hard to talk about Sansa’s narrative and NOT talk about fairy tales, since they are referenced so often and so closely entwined with her story.

I’ve talked before about how there are obvious references to the Beauty and the Beast tale in Sansa’s marriage to Tyrion. I’m also quite fond of this interpretation of Sansa and Tyrion as Cupid and Psyche, and that myth has long been considered the prototype of all Beauty and the Beast stories. It also belongs to a class of tale known as “the search for the lost husband,” of which one of the most well known stories is the Norwegian answer to Beauty and the Beast, titled East of the Sun and West of the Moon.

In the latter story, a young woman is taken by a great white bear to live in his castle, and given all the things she could need in the world. At night, she is visited by a mysterious man whose face she cannot see, and who is always gone by morning. The beats here are much the same as the Cupid and Psyche story. Psyche cannot see her lover’s face but comes to know him as very dear to her, despite being originally told that she would be wed to a monster.

Does this sound familiar?

“Don’t lie, Sansa. I am malformed, scarred, and small, but …” she could see him groping “… abed, when the candles are blown out, I am made no worse than other men. In the dark, I am the Knight of Flowers." 

In East of the Sun and West of the Moon, the young maiden is warned by her mother that it might actually be a troll that she is sleeping with, and told to light a candle when he is sleeping so that she can look upon his face. The same thing happens to Psyche, who is also told to light a candle so that she can see who really comes to visit her at night.

…when the candles are blown out…

Of course, as in many tales, breaking the enchantment of night causes the magic to dissolve, and now that the young maiden has seen his face, the enchanted husband must leave her. In many versions of the story this is treated as a betrayal by the female protagonist of the story, although it is one of ignorance and lack of trust, rather than malice, understandable when one is dealing with an enchanted husband. Similarly, Sansa’s “betrayal” of Tyrion is not really a betrayal of him, as she bears him no ill will and is merely fleeing for her own survival and acting as an unwitting pawn in the game that the Tyrells and Littlefinger are playing.

In the Search for the Lost Husband, both husband and wife are separated by magic and physical distance. There are variations on the story, and parallels with other stories of enchanted brides and grooms. Sansa’s story also has parallels with the animal bride tales that pop up in various cultures, the most well-known of which is probably the Japanese Crane Wife tale, which is also a story about a lost spouse.

“The northern girl. Winterfell’s daughter. We heard she killed the king with a spell, and afterward changed into a wolf with big leather wings like a bat, and flew out a tower window. But she left the dwarf behind and Cersei means to have his head.”

That’s stupid, Arya thought. Sansa only knows songs, not spells, and she’d never marry the Imp. 

In the Search for the Lost Husband, the young woman eventually is able to find and reunite with her enchanted husband after a long journey in which she must undergo many arduous tasks, and then she is able to finally lift the curse that prevents them from being together. These stories are largely female driven and it is the female protagonist who is the hero of the story, who reunites with and saves her love after undergoing her own journey of self growth and discovery.

I’d argue that both Sansa and Tyrion take on both the role of the enchanted bride/groom at various parts in the narrative, and the role of the hero/heroine who must search for their lost spouse and undergo a test of self along the way. Both are sent into exile, and both must undergo hardships and journeys of self-discovery where their very selves will be tested.

I’d also argue that Tyrion is undergoing his own search, for his lost first wife (who was also not who Tyrion believed her to be), although I don’t think he’ll find Tysha. Similarly, Sansa is currently hiding in the Vale and being pursued by various suitors who are often not what they appear to be. I do think that Tyrion and Sansa will reunite in the books, though, and that their marriage is still important to the narrative and will be important in future books.

Of course, as in many tales, breaking the enchantment of night causes the magic to dissolve, and now that the young maiden has seen his face, the enchanted husband must leave her. In many versions of the story this is treated as a betrayal by the female protagonist of the story, although it is one of ignorance and lack of trust, rather than malice, understandable when one is dealing with an enchanted husband. Similarly, Sansa’s “betrayal” of Tyrion is not really a betrayal of him, as she bears him no ill will and is merely fleeing for her own survival and acting as an unwitting pawn in the game that the Tyrells and Littlefinger are playing.

In the Search for the Lost Husband, both husband and wife are separated by magic and physical distance. There are variations on the story, and parallels with other stories of enchanted brides and grooms. Sansa’s story also has parallels with the animal bride tales that pop up in various cultures, the most well-known of which is probably the Japanese Crane Wife tale, which is also a story about a lost spouse.

“The northern girl. Winterfell’s daughter. We heard she killed the king with a spell, and afterward changed into a wolf with big leather wings like a bat, and flew out a tower window. But she left the dwarf behind and Cersei means to have his head.”

That’s stupid, Arya thought. Sansa only knows songs, not spells, and she’d never marry the Imp. 

In the Search for the Lost Husband, the young woman eventually is able to find and reunite with her enchanted husband after a long journey in which she must undergo many arduous tasks, and then she is able to finally lift the curse that prevents them from being together. These stories are largely female driven and it is the female protagonist who is the hero of the story, who reunites with and saves her love after undergoing her own journey of self growth and discovery.

I’d argue that both Sansa and Tyrion take on both the role of the enchanted bride/groom at various parts in the narrative, and the role of the hero/heroine who must search for their lost spouse and undergo a test of self along the way. Both are sent into exile, and both must undergo hardships and journeys of self-discovery where their very selves will be tested.

I’d also argue that Tyrion is undergoing his own search, for his lost first wife (who was also not who Tyrion believed her to be), although I don’t think he’ll find Tysha. Similarly, Sansa is currently hiding in the Vale and being pursued by various suitors who are often not what they appear to be. I do think that Tyrion and Sansa will reunite in the books, though, and that their marriage is still important to the narrative and will be important in future books.
trail.content:
It’s hard to talk about Sansa’s narrative and NOT talk about fairy tales, since they are referenced so often and so closely entwined with her story.

I’ve talked before about how there are obvious references to the Beauty and the Beast tale in Sansa’s marriage to Tyrion. I’m also quite fond of this interpretation of Sansa and Tyrion as Cupid and Psyche, and that myth has long been considered the prototype of all Beauty and the Beast stories. It also belongs to a class of tale known as “the search for the lost husband,” of which one of the most well known stories is the Norwegian answer to Beauty and the Beast, titled East of the Sun and West of the Moon.

In the latter story, a young woman is taken by a great white bear to live in his castle, and given all the things she could need in the world. At night, she is visited by a mysterious man whose face she cannot see, and who is always gone by morning. The beats here are much the same as the Cupid and Psyche story. Psyche cannot see her lover’s face but comes to know him as very dear to her, despite being originally told that she would be wed to a monster.

Does this sound familiar?

“Don’t lie, Sansa. I am malformed, scarred, and small, but …” she could see him groping “… abed, when the candles are blown out, I am made no worse than other men. In the dark, I am the Knight of Flowers." 

In East of the Sun and West of the Moon, the young maiden is warned by her mother that it might actually be a troll that she is sleeping with, and told to light a candle when he is sleeping so that she can look upon his face. The same thing happens to Psyche, who is also told to light a candle so that she can see who really comes to visit her at night.

…when the candles are blown out…

Of course, as in many tales, breaking the enchantment of night causes the magic to dissolve, and now that the young maiden has seen his face, the enchanted husband must leave her. In many versions of the story this is treated as a betrayal by the female protagonist of the story, although it is one of ignorance and lack of trust, rather than malice, understandable when one is dealing with an enchanted husband. Similarly, Sansa’s “betrayal” of Tyrion is not really a betrayal of him, as she bears him no ill will and is merely fleeing for her own survival and acting as an unwitting pawn in the game that the Tyrells and Littlefinger are playing.

In the Search for the Lost Husband, both husband and wife are separated by magic and physical distance. There are variations on the story, and parallels with other stories of enchanted brides and grooms. Sansa’s story also has parallels with the animal bride tales that pop up in various cultures, the most well-known of which is probably the Japanese Crane Wife tale, which is also a story about a lost spouse.

“The northern girl. Winterfell’s daughter. We heard she killed the king with a spell, and afterward changed into a wolf with big leather wings like a bat, and flew out a tower window. But she left the dwarf behind and Cersei means to have his head.”

That’s stupid, Arya thought. Sansa only knows songs, not spells, and she’d never marry the Imp. 

In the Search for the Lost Husband, the young woman eventually is able to find and reunite with her enchanted husband after a long journey in which she must undergo many arduous tasks, and then she is able to finally lift the curse that prevents them from being together. These stories are largely female driven and it is the female protagonist who is the hero of the story, who reunites with and saves her love after undergoing her own journey of self growth and discovery.

I’d argue that both Sansa and Tyrion take on both the role of the enchanted bride/groom at various parts in the narrative, and the role of the hero/heroine who must search for their lost spouse and undergo a test of self along the way. Both are sent into exile, and both must undergo hardships and journeys of self-discovery where their very selves will be tested.

I’d also argue that Tyrion is undergoing his own search, for his lost first wife (who was also not who Tyrion believed her to be), although I don’t think he’ll find Tysha. Similarly, Sansa is currently hiding in the Vale and being pursued by various suitors who are often not what they appear to be. I do think that Tyrion and Sansa will reunite in the books, though, and that their marriage is still important to the narrative and will be important in future books.

blog.name: maxbetta
blog.title: Sansan & Fanfiction
blog.description:
I ❤️Sansan

Proud member of the Hound’s Harem

Maxbetta on AO3

Bookworm - Aspiring knitter - Hygge enthusiast Caffeine addict - Pub trivia nerd - Mug collector

Sometimes I make inappropriate jokes

body:
A predictive text Sansan ficlet

The title of this ficlet is:

“Oh my god I’m so glad you got married and you don’t know how much I love it “


Sandor was my morning sourdough toast with matcha latte yum.

Sansa is a great night to drink coffee and tea flavored coffee.

Together, they have been taken care to be in the same old years ago but it is still very nice.

The end is the first thing that you could get in the car. They will do a good breakfast for lunch or lunch and lunch dinner tonight.

The moral of the story is:

“When life’s not to a good way of making it look like you have to be the perfect one for the kids and the people that they have in their own life is the way they do they have a great time.”

blog.name: gendrybaratheonn
blog.title: All I know is that you're beautiful and I love you
blog.description:
Juliana, 31, Brasil. Arya, Ian, Mickey, Sam and Derek defender. Gendry Baratheon stan. 
Arya x Gendry
is canon, fuck that ending.

tags: they growing up and changing and understanding that it's part of the growth process
Obviously Sansa had the worst moments of her life directly related to men
But at this point it's not just trauma imo
It's her realization that she doesn't need a marriage
She has the loyalty of all the northerners
She can lead the North as she was doing while Jon was south trying to convince Dany to help
She showed how much she understands ruling and how good she is at it
*she also has the loyalty of the knights of the vale. Her not littlefinger
And Arya went through so much and probably never had an opportunity to explore her feelings towards men
She had a crush on Gendry when she was 12/13 and then got separated from him and now they met again
And oh he's hella fine I guess that crush didn't die at all just took a years long nap
I can't believe Game of Thrones is making me this happy
summary: The fact that Sansa, who had all those dreams about knights and princes, learned she needs no men by her side to be whole and...
body: The fact that Sansa, who had all those dreams about knights and princes, learned she needs no men by her side to be whole and powerful and Arya, who seemed to reject all romantic notions took the first step into a romantic relationship honestly is so, so important to me!

reblog.comment: The fact that Sansa, who had all those dreams about knights and princes, learned she needs no men by her side to be whole and powerful and Arya, who seemed to reject all romantic notions took the first step into a romantic relationship honestly is so, so important to me!

question: Sansa
answer:
Queen in the North! Sansa writes Arya a letter every week and visits her sister when she can, although it gets harder and harder once they both have kids.


Put a name in my inbox and I’ll give you a headcanon about them from my ADoD universe.

summary: Is anyone else upset we haven’t gotten a Sansa and Sandor reunion? You don’t have to ship them or anything but you have to admit...
body: Is anyone else upset we haven’t gotten a Sansa and Sandor reunion? You don’t have to ship them or anything but you have to admit he cared about and protected her so much, especially in the books. I feel like it’s weird to not even show them meeting again.

reblog.comment: Is anyone else upset we haven’t gotten a Sansa and Sandor reunion? You don’t have to ship them or anything but you have to admit he cared about and protected her so much, especially in the books. I feel like it’s weird to not even show them meeting again.

trail.content_raw: Is anyone else upset we haven’t gotten a Sansa and Sandor reunion? You don’t have to ship them or anything but you have to admit he cared about and protected her so much, especially in the books. I feel like it’s weird to not even show them meeting again.
trail.content: Is anyone else upset we haven’t gotten a Sansa and Sandor reunion? You don’t have to ship them or anything but you have to admit he cared about and protected her so much, especially in the books. I feel like it’s weird to not even show them meeting again.
